node.title: EU demands China 'provide verifiable proof' tennis star Peng Shuai is safe
node.alt: A photo of Peng Shuai serving wearing red with black background.
node.description: The European Union joins groups around the world raising concerns about the tennis star in the wake of her alleging she was sexually assaulted by a former top Chinese official.
node.content:
["The European Union is calling\u00a0on Beijing\u00a0to show proof of tennis star Peng Shuai's wellbeing, joining groups around the world concerned about her fate since she alleged she was sexually assault by a former top Chinese official.", "\"The EU joins growing international demands, including by sport professionals, for assurances that she is free and not under threat,\" the EU's foreign service said in a statement.", "The bloc also urged Chinese authorities to carry out a \"full, fair and transparent investigation into her allegations of sexual assault\".", "", "
Many are concerned for Peng Shuai, who accused a high-profile official\u00a0of sexual assault.(AP: Mark Schiefelbein, file)
", "The whereabouts of Ms Peng, a former doubles world number one, became a matter of concern when she disappeared on November\u00a02 after posting a message on social media alleging that China's former vice-premier, Zhang Gaoli, had sexually assaulted her.", "The tennis player's post was removed within minutes, and she stopped appearing in public.\u00a0", "She reappeared in mid-November in Beijing and held a video call with International Olympic Committee (IOC) president Thomas Bach.", "But the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) said this did not address or alleviate concerns about her health and safety, and the EU agreed.\u00a0", "\"Her recent public reappearance does not ease concerns about her safety and freedom,\"\u00a0an EU spokesperson said.\u00a0", "A phone number at the Chinese embassy in Brussels was not answered on Tuesday (local time).\u00a0", "Neither Mr Zhang nor the Chinese government have commented on Ms Peng's allegations, although Beijing has told foreign governments not to interfere in its affairs.", "The topic has been blocked from direct discussion on China's internet.", "Ms Peng adds to a growing number of Chinese businesspeople, activists and ordinary people who have disappeared from public view in recent years after criticising party figures or in crackdowns on corruption or pro-democracy and labour-rights campaigns.\u00a0\u00a0\"The EU strongly opposes the use of the practice of enforced disappearance and arbitrary detention \u2026 and calls upon China to comply with its human rights obligations under national and international law,\"\u00a0the EU said.", "Reuters/AP"]
